title: How much of 'Guns, Germs, and Steel' is historically accurate? - Quora

response.answer_text: It is not an issue of whether GGS is a “historically accurate” book. It is not a history text. It is really a hybrid popular anthropological/historical work—Diamond is an anthropologist. Diamond’s anthropological and historical descriptions are accurate enough as I recall. I don’t think there has been a lot of criticism of the work saying that Diamond got his facts wrong. Where people have differences with the author is in his thesis. That thesis is that environmental conditions are determinative, pretty much to the effective exclusion of almost all other factors, with respect to how societies evolve. I don’t think any reasonable person would dispute that environment plays, and has played, a significant role in the way societies develop, it is a question of degree. Diamond’s thesis is like mother’s milk to modern world historians who largely see their mission as playing down the Western orientation of histories written before the latter half of the 20th Century. A problem in this project is explaining the rise of West without attributing any special worthiness to Western accomplishments or culture. Diamond’s thesis is that basically the West got lucky, and by implication that luck will eventually run out. World historians, who like most academics tend to lean left, like that. His critics tend to be traditional classicists and the like—Victor Davis Hanson is one—who find Diamond’s approach to history and anthropology something akin to B.F. Skinner’s work in psychology. I’ve taught World History for 20 years, and keep a copy of GGS near my desk, though I don’t reference it a lot. I think it is a good book, with a lot of truths in it, though tendentiously written at times. I like Diamond’s “The Third Chimpanzee” (much more a work of pure popular anthropology) better.

The explanations provided in Jarad Diamond’s “Guns, Germs, and Steel” for the collapse and ultimate disappearance of Norse settlements in Greenland have been challenged and refuted. Where the author sees over explotación of resources and inability to adapt to changing climate, others see an society adapting to changes in climate, and facing economic challenges because of the fall of demand for the societies only export, walrus tusks. Why did Greenland’s Vikings disappear? Cultural adaptation, compounding vulnerabilities and conjunctures in Norse Greenland The author’s explanation for the disappearance of the complex society and a large part of the population on Easter Island: cultural based over explotación of local resources, has been challenged by others who have suggested more complex explanations, including the introduction of rats by the first Polynesian settlers and the introduction of European diseases and slave raiding after the arrival of Europeans to the Americas. How a sustainable society has been falsely blamed for its own demise The myth of Easter Island’s ecocide Although, the case for dismissing Diamond’s ideas about collapse on Easter Island is not so strong as that for Greenland. http://eprints.lse.ac.uk/27864/1/WP117.pdf Diamond’s blame of over exploration of local resources for the abandonment of classical Mayan city states has also been challenged. For example The Maya Forest: Destroyed or cultivated by the ancient Maya?
